bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jose A. Presno, December 6, 1944

div1.p: In a letter of introduction to the Cuban Minister of Public Health and Sanitation, Hench requests assistance in protecting a building at the site of Camp Lazear. He discusses his plans to create a museum dedicated to the conquest of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jose A. Presno, December 6, 1944
div1.opener:
PSH/cb
6 December, 1944
His Excellency Doctor Jose A. Presno
Minister of Public Health and Sanitation
Habana, Cuba
Your Excellency:
div1.p:
For several years I have been greatly interested in the story
of the conquest of yellow fever and the work of Doctor Finlay and the
American Yellow Fever Commission. I believe our mutual friend, Mr.
John J. Moran, has told you how we discovered the long lost Camp Lazear
and the remains of the little building where so much of the experimental
work was done. It is a curious and most happy coincidence that that same
plot of ground, the Finca San Jose, was the site of at least a few of
Doctor Finlay's own early experiments. I have proof of this, as it was
told me by Doctor Finlay's own son and is mentioned by the latter in his
book about his father. For these many reasons, it has been my hope that
a sufficient amount of money might be collected to memorialize the remains
of Camp Lazear and the little building. I have been collecting some money
in this country. I don't have much but it is a start; I have about $1200
on hand and the Mayo Clinic and Mayo Foundation have promised that, contin-
gent on the receipt of other funds, they will contribute up to $10,000.
We will need more than that, as it is my hope that we can enclose the
remains of the little shack in a nice permanent structure, which will con-
stitute a museum to the conquest of yellow fever. I am so hopeful that in
this museum, we can display many interesting and historically valuable
souvenirs, not only of the work of Doctor Finlay, but also of the work of
the American Commission. I have already collected many items for such a
future display.

I have discussed these plans on more than one occasion with
Doctor Domingo Ramos, and once with Senor Macia, the present owner of the
property. My furtherance of this venture has been interrupted markedly
since my entrance into the military service; nevertheless, I have been
keeping slowly at the project, and Mr. John Moran of Habana, has given me
invaluable support. I have asked him to act as my agent in any plans that
we can make in Habana.

At present, I am greatly concerned about the condition of the
little building. Mr. Moran has assured me it survived the recent hurricane,
and I am most anxious to have it properly supported, either by a strong,
completely enveloping semi-permanent, temporary wooden structure, or in
some other equally effective manner, so that it may be protected until such
time as we can properly house it in a permanent building.

Permit me to send you a reprint of a little article that I published
three or four years ago. Also, permit me to tell you that I am not at all

interested in any argument as to who deserves the greater honor, Doctor
Finlay or any member of the American Commission. There is great glory
for all, and it is my hope to enlist the American Medical Profession in
this country in this historical venture, to the end that we may honor
Doctor Finlay and his Cuban colleagues equally and in their proper place
in relation to members of the American Commission. I am so hopeful that
this little venture will lead to a closer union of spirit of the Medical
Profession of this country and of Cuba.

If you have any suggestion or advice you could give me by
correspondence or to be given to me by direct communication with Mr. Moran,
we would be most grateful. To identify myself, may I say that I have been
on the staff of the Mayo Clinic since 1921 and have been in the Army since
1942. I am Chief of the Medical Service and Director of the Army's Rheumatism
Center here at the Army and Navy General Hospital, which happens to be the
oldest general hospital in the United States Army. Some months ago I had
the honor to present an illustrated lecture on the conquest of yellow fever
before the staff of this hospital, and it was received with a very enthusiast-
ic reception.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, PHILIP S. HENCH, Lt. Col., M.C.
Chief of the Medical Service Enc. - “Conquerors of Yellow Fever”
